slides.text: The study got a bit of attention on dozens of outlets. The headline: A personâ€™s ability to be random peaks at 25 years old and declines after 60.
We initially set out to use the findings to make an age guessing game, but after analyzing the data we lost confidence it would yield good results. So now this story is about the replication crisis.

This is the replication crisis in two quotes from the Vox article: â€œOne 2015 attempt to reproduce 100 psychology studies was able to replicate only 39 of them.â€ And â€œin some ways, the culture of academia actively selects for bad research. Pressure to publish lots of papers favors those who can put them together quickly â€” and one way to be quick is to be willing to cut corners.â€
Instead of adding one more abstracted data point to the heap of reviewed studies, we want to show you just how easy it is to fall into this trap, and highlight how little decisions have big effects.

Our issue with the study about randomness was the decision to include â€œbadâ€ responses. To us, a bad response meant that the participant either misunderstood the instructions, or intentionally sabotaged the experiment. That decision was the difference between â€œah this is interestingâ€ and â€œwelp, nothing hereâ€ (or â€œnull resultsâ€ in statistics lingo).
